column1: The start of settlement was likely due to there being a crossing over the river Werse
column2: which was also the crossing of two key roads (Hamm–Ahlen–Warendorf and Beckum–Ahlen–Herbern)

column2: the fledgling settlement was built around an episcopal court. Within the safe haven of this church fortification
column3: the first settlers were craftsmen and merchants who traded with the local farmers and peasants of the court.

column1: Long-distance trading started in the second half of the 12th century — proof being the names of Ahlen merchants found on invoices from merchants in Lübeck. Ahlen was also part of the north German Hanse. During this time a town wall with five towers was built (about 1271). The stripping away of the town wall had begun in the year 1765 and the last hint of it was gone by 1929.
Ahlen grew quickly during the 13th century and in or about the year 1285
column2: the population was so high that a new church (St. Marien) was founded next to the old one (St. Bartholomäus). This leads to the likelihood that Ahlen was one of the 18 biggest towns in Westphalia
the town's growth was hindered in the 14th century by the Black Death. According to the town's census book of 1389
column3: only 63 families were left in Ahlen. But the town rebounded. In 1454
column4: a citizen list showed 212 families living in Ahlen; seven noble families and their attendants lived in the episcopal court as well. Based on this number of families
column6: 300 citizens would be realistic. By this time the town had four quarters — all of which being about the same size and each quarter being named after its own town gate.

column1: Each quarter was responsible for defending its part of the town wall and gate.

column1: About 20 documents of witch trials during the time from 1574 until 1652 survive. The hunt for witches started in 1574 with the death of four women. Thereafter
column2: Peter Kleikamp was charged with being a werewolf; he was tortured and burned alive on the pyre. In 1616
column3: Christian zum Loe was charged with wizardry; he went insane and died while in jail. The last known case was in 1652 against Anna Sadelers; she was tortured
column4: burned alive on the pyre and beheaded.
